conclusion: Electric-energy gain in every gap: Each time the electron crosses a gap it falls through the potential difference U.
Kinetic energy gained in one gap: ΔK = eU
Speed when it has just crossed the first gap: v₁ = √(2 eU / m)
While the electron is travelling inside a metal cylinder the field is zero, so the motion is uniform.
To ensure the field in the next gap has the correct direction, the electron must spend exactly half an a.c. period (T/2) inside every cylinder.
Flight-time in cylinder n: tₙ = Lₙ / vₙ = T/2
Before entering cylinder n the electron has already crossed the gaps 0–1, 1–2, … , (n-1)–n, hence has been accelerated n times.
Total kinetic energy Kₙ = n eU = ½ m vₙ², vₙ = √(2 n eU / m)
Length of the n-th cylinder: Lₙ = (T/2) √(2 n eU / m)
Motion from the start to the exit of cylinder 2: Gap 0–1 (t ≈ 0): electron accelerated, speed becomes v₁ = √(2 eU/m).
Cylinder 1: uniform motion, time T/2, length L₁ = (T/2) v₁.
Gap 1–2 (t ≈ T/2): another acceleration, kinetic energy becomes 2 eU, speed v₂ = √(4 eU/m) = √2 v₁.
Cylinder 2: uniform motion, time T/2, length L₂ = (T/2) v₂.
At t = T the electron emerges from cylinder 2 ready to be accelerated in the gap 2–3.
Velocity on entering cylinder 1: v₁ = √(2 eU / m)
Required length of the n-th cylinder: Lₙ = (T/2) √(2 n eU / m) (n = 1, 2, 3, …)
